Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Two-dimensional wave patterns and physical applications of Kadomtsev-Petviashvili web-solitons
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative research project to investigate certain types of nonlinear wave phenomena. Due to their inherent nonlinear behavior, such waves have very important physical applications in the generation of large amplitude waves, for example in shallow water near a beach. A primary goal of this research is to provide further insights into possible mechanisms that generate extremely high waves frequently observed in open seas and along coastlines. Important examples of such phenomena include tsunamis. Understanding the nature and dynamics of such extreme waves, particularly in oceans near highly populated coastal areas, is a significant and urgent task. The research activities will involve undergraduate and graduate students who will be trained in the field of applied mathematics and will gain first-hand research experience. It is further anticipated that the results from the proposed work would be useful in the study of similar nonlinear wave phenomena that occur in other physical problems including nonlinear optics, plasmas, and spin waves in magnetic thin films.

The nonlinear waves indicated above are closely described by the weakly dispersive, quasi-two-dimensional Kadomtsev-Petviashvili (KP) equation which admits a class of solitary wave solutions with complex two-dimensional web patterns. These solutions are sometimes referred to as the KP web-solitons.The purpose of this collaborative research project is to continue investigations into the physical as well as the mathematical aspects of the KP equation. Broadly speaking, this project has two main goals that are interrelated, namely, (1) to study solitary wave interactions observed in certain physical situations such as shallow water where the KP equation describes the leading order model, and (2) to investigate the detailed structure of the complex two-dimensional patterns of the KP web-solitons using geometric and combinatorial theories, which bring new techniques to the area of nonlinear waves. In particular, detailed analytical and numerical studies of the interactions, stability and initial value problem of the KP web-solitons will be conducted in this project. Furthermore, the project envisions collaboration with experimentalists in order to compare the obtained theoretical results with laboratory experiments performed in water wave tanks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the project supported by this award is to develope analytical and numerical methods to investigate the solitary wave solutions of the Kadomtsev-Petvishvili (KP) equation and their  physical applications. The KP equation is a two-dimensional nonlinear dispersive wave equation which arises as the leading order approximation under long wave, small amplitude and quasi-two dimensionality assumptions. The solitary wave solutions of the KP equation  generate complex two-dimensional web-like structures,  these solutions are sometimes referred to as the KP web-solitons. 

Over the past several years, the PI, together with S. Chakravarty (collaborative rsearch partner), has investigated several problems related to the mathematical  structure and interaction properties of the KP web-solitons. They have classified  and characterized large classes of previously unknown web-soliton solutions using  algebraic combinatorics and theory of Grassmannians from algebraic geometry. Some of these solutions have important applications in the study of resonant interaction of solitary waves in shallow water, and have been reproduced in laboratory experiments of water waves.

In this collaborative reserach project, the PI had continued his study on the KP equation and explored several issues which are mathematically significant as well as physically relevant. The project was mainly focused on the following two categories:

(1) Study solitary wave interactions observed in certain physical situations such as shallow water where the KP equation describes the leading order model.

(2) Investigate the detailed structure of the complex two-dimensional patterns of the KP web-solitons  using geometric and combinatorial theories, which bring new techniques to the area of nonlinear waves.

The proposed project aimed to undertake an in-depth study of the KP web-solitons. In particular, detailed analytical and numerical  studies of the interactions, stability and initial value problem of the KP web-solitons were conducted in this project.  The PI proposed to design algorithms to construct exact KP soliton solutions from the physical (metric) data from a wave pattern by utilizing ideas from  dynamical system theory, representation theory and algebraic combinatorics. The PI also collaborated with experimentalists to compare the theoretical results with laboratory experiments performed in water wave tanks.

The main outcome of this project is a development of the theory of two-dimensional  wave phenomena associated with a nonlinear equation of physical importance, and help advance their  understanding in a unified mathematical framework. A broad range of  methods from both pure and applied mathematics were implemented in this research. Results obtained from this project elucidate fundamental connections that exist between integrable systems and other mathematical areas such as combinatorics, geometry and  representation theory. These results are summarized in the PI's recent book ``KP solitons and the Grassmannians", which was published in 2017.

This project involves the study of nonlinear wave phenomena which manifests in nature as hurricanes and tsunamis as well as in innovations such as high speed data  transmissions, and is of great importance in physical sciences. The results of this project provide useful information regarding surface wave patterns in shallow water and high elevation ``rogue'' waves known to occur during tsunamis. Furthermore, the problems proposed in this project are shared by two-dimensional nonlinear wave phenomena in various other important physical areas including plasma physics, optics, and ferromagnetics. The results from this project were disseminated through archival journal articles and conference presentations. This collaborative project have involved graduate students from the Ohio State University  and undergraduate students from University of Colorado, Colorado Springs. The PIs were strongly committed to help foster the training and education of these students by offering a variety of research topics from the proposed project.
